definitions.definition: if you nod, nod your head or your head nods, you move your head up and down to show agreement, understanding, etc.

examples.text: I asked him if he would help me and he nodded.
‘Ready?’ She nodded at me and we set off.
Her head nodded in agreement.
He nodded his head sympathetically.
She nodded approval.
Everyone nodded their agreement.
‘That's exactly it,’ she said, nodding vigorously.
Ashamed, I could only nod.
He nodded absently, his mind obviously on other things.
He nodded with satisfaction.
She could not speak but just nodded mutely.
She nodded gently to herself.
She nodded in agreement.
She nodded sagely as she listened.
‘Is this the right way?’ she asked. The man nodded.
She nodded her approval.

definitions.definition: to move your head down and up once to say hello or goodbye to somebody or to give them a sign to do something
definitions.sensetop: nod (to/at somebody)nod to/at somebody to do somethingnod something (to/at somebody)

examples.text: The president nodded to the crowd as he passed in the motorcade.
She nodded at him to begin speaking
examples.contextForm: nod to/at somebody to do something

examples.text: to nod a greeting
Michael nodded a greeting to the other visitors.
She nodded to Duncan as she left.
He nodded curtly and walked away.
They nodded at us, so we nodded back.

definitions.definition: to move your head in the direction of somebody/something to show that you are talking about them/it

examples.text: I asked where Steve was and she nodded in the direction of the kitchen.
She nodded towards his suitcase. ‘Going somewhere?’ she asked.
‘Let's go!’ he said, nodding towards/​toward the door.
Maria nodded towards the open door.

definitions.definition: to let your head fall forward when you are sleeping in a chair

examples.text: He sat nodding in front of the fire.

wordOrigin: late Middle English (as a verb): perhaps of Low German origin; compare with Middle High German notten ‘move about, shake’. The noun dates from the mid 16th cent.
